name: Al-Furqaan Foundation
mission: To inform and educate all the residents of the United States the truth about Islam and its core principals and to counter the negative media information...
zakatClaimEvidence: Al-Furqaan Foundation explicitly states, "Donate your zakat today." Additionally, their donation process includes an option to "Select Boxes. Choose the number of boxes and select Zakat/Sadaqa." and on their donation page, there is a choice between "Sadaqa or Zakat". (Source: https://furqaan.org/donate/)

all_citations.claim: The organization reported a program expense ratio of 89.3%.
Total revenue for the period was $3,249,437.
The foundation manages significant assets related to book distribution value.
Core programs include the Furqaan Project and The Clear Islam, offering various online products.
The foundation provides options for Zakat-eligible donations.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The foundation earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and Zakat eligibility, balanced against a lack of independent impact verification.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact data regarding long-term educational outcomes
Moderate data confidence levels based on available public filings

dimension_explanations.alignment: The foundation offers a medium donor fit for those seeking to support religious education and cultural outreach [5]. Its mission to address media misinformation highlights a specific cause urgency within the religious-cultural sector [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates a high level of financial health with a total revenue of $3,249,437 and a program expense ratio of 89.3% [1][2]. While it focuses on capacity building through book distribution and online products, the direct cost per beneficiary remains unverified by external sources [3][4].

baseline_narrative.headline: Al-Furqaan Foundation is a Zakat-eligible organization dedicated to educating the American public on the core principles of Islam through large-scale distribution and outreach programs.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.3% ensuring most funds reach core initiatives
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.01 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 25.1 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: The Al-Furqaan Foundation operates several key initiatives including the Furqaan Project, Furqaan Dawah Center, and The Clear Islam to counter negative media narratives and provide authentic information about Islamic faith [4]. As a Zakat-eligible entity, the foundation facilitates religious giving to support its mission of informing all residents of the United States [5].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The foundation earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and Zakat eligibility, balanced against a lack of independent impact verification.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization operates with a <cite id="2">board of only 2 members</cite>, which falls significantly short of best practices for independent oversight.
There is a lack of published beneficiary counts, making it difficult to assess the <cite id="4">cost per beneficiary</cite> of its programs.
The organization has seen a contraction in funding, with a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of -4.1%</cite>.

bbb_assessment.summary: Not evaluated by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains excellent financial reserves and low overhead costs, mitigating immediate operational risks.
risk_factors: <cite id="2">Board consists of only 2 members</cite>, limiting independent oversight
<cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of -4.1%</cite> indicates shrinking financial support
Lack of rigorous third-party impact evaluations for educational outcomes
case_against.summary: The primary concerns regarding Al-Furqaan Foundation center on its governance structure and recent revenue trends.

confidence.notes: Data confidence is moderate due to reliance on older tax filings and lack of detailed impact metrics.

alignment.explanation: The alignment score (31/50) reflects its status as a <cite id="5">Zakat-eligible organization</cite> serving the religious cultural space, having been established in <cite id="2">2003</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

credibility.explanation: Credibility is mixed; while the organization publishes <cite id="3">audited financial statements</cite>, it suffers from weak governance due to having only <cite id="2">2 board members</cite>, leading to a risk deduction.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the foundation must expand its board of directors to at least five independent members to ensure proper oversight.

impact.explanation: The impact score (26/50) is driven by an excellent <cite id="2">89.3% program expense ratio</cite> and strong <cite id="1">working capital reserves</cite>, but is limited by the absence of a documented theory of change and missing cost-per-beneficiary data.
impact.improvement: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed, and document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Output tracking but limited outcome evaluation

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service and material distribution rather than grantmaking.

rich_narrative.headline: Al-Furqaan Foundation is a Zakat-eligible organization dedicated to educating the American public on the core principles of Islam through large-scale distribution and outreach programs.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to fund Islamic educational outreach, prison dawah, and the distribution of religious materials across North America.
donor_motivations: Want to support dawah and Islamic education in the US and Canada
Seek to fulfill zakat obligations under the fisabilillah category
Value organizations with extremely low overhead and fundraising costs
giving_considerations: Governance structure is unusually small for an organization of this size
Impact is measured primarily in materials distributed rather than long-term behavioral changes
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking rigorous academic evidence of impact or those who prioritize organizations with strong, independent board governance.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C indicates that the organization tracks outputs (like book distribution value) but lacks rigorous third-party evaluations of long-term educational outcomes.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The organization operates on the implicit theory that distributing authentic Islamic literature and providing educational resources will counter negative media narratives and foster better understanding of Islam.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: In educational outreach, tracking outputs (books distributed) is important, but measuring actual shifts in understanding or community relations provides stronger proof of mission success.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With declining revenue but strong reserves, the organization has capacity to absorb funding to revitalize its growth trajectory.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its specific focus on <cite id="4">prison outreach and Braille materials</cite> alongside general distribution.
peer_comparison.peer_group: Islamic educational and dawah organizations in North America

similar_organizations.differentiator: Stronger focus on direct convert support
similar_organizations.name: GainPeace

strengths.detail: The foundation directs <cite id="2">89.3% of its budget to program expenses</cite>, ensuring the vast majority of donations directly support its educational and dawah initiatives.
The organization operates with extremely low fundraising costs, spending only <cite id="1">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>.
The charity maintains robust reserves, holding <cite id="1">25.1 months of working capital</cite> to weather economic downturns.

strengths_deep_dive: Al-Furqaan Foundation demonstrates exceptional financial efficiency in its core operations. With <cite id="2">$3,249,437 in total revenue</cite>, the organization manages to allocate <cite id="2">89.3% of its budget to program expenses</cite>, well above industry standards for educational nonprofits. This efficiency is further highlighted by its fundraising metrics, costing just <cite id="1">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>. The organization's financial stability is secured by its substantial reserves, providing <cite id="1">25.1 months of working capital</cite>, which allows it to maintain long-term projects like <cite id="4">Islam in Prison and Dawah in Braille</cite> without immediate funding pressure.
rich_narrative.summary: The Al-Furqaan Foundation is an established Islamic educational organization founded in <cite id="2">2003</cite> that focuses on distributing authentic information about Islam across North America. The organization operates several core initiatives, including the <cite id="4">Furqaan Project, Furqaan Dawah Center, and Islam in Prison</cite>, aiming to counter negative media narratives and educate the public. Financially, the foundation reported <cite id="2">$3,249,437 in total revenue</cite> for the 2020 tax year. It demonstrates strong operational efficiency, directing <cite id="2">89.3% of its budget to program expenses</cite>. The organization is highly efficient in its fundraising efforts, spending just <cite id="1">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>. As a <cite id="5">Zakat-eligible organization</cite>, it accepts religious dues under the fisabilillah category to fund its outreach and educational materials. The foundation has a strong track record of material distribution, noting a <cite id="3">book distribution value of $855,697</cite> in its 2019 audited financials. However, the organization faces governance challenges, operating with a <cite id="2">board of only 2 members</cite>, and has experienced a recent contraction in funding with a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of -4.1%</cite>. Despite these challenges, it maintains exceptional liquidity with <cite id="1">25.1 months of working capital</cite> available to sustain its operations.
